message: I would love to know the best practices for stuff like the filesystem the db is running on.
i've got postgis, indexing, partitioning, windowing functions, PLs, tuning, HA and connection pooling.
Is understanding the query planner advanced enough? I don't mean knowing that it exists, but actually how it decides what to do.
oh totally. there's so much good performance stuff you can get out of a few filesystem tweaks!
Yeah, query planner is advanced :) Well, understanding the different operators, at least the most common ones, is pretty important.
listen / notify!  one of my favorite features in postgresql and people rarely seem to talk about it.
ahh yes. good one. also analyze: what is it good for?
awesome! also newly improved with non-bloat inducing properties!
yeah, I'm loving the new features added to listen / notify in 9
off to grab some dinner... convore is pretty interesting!  have fun, postgres-people.
Also, there should be a section on generating mandlebrot fractals with SQL
Oh darn, its using T-SQL. I thought i saw one that was a straight up SQL. http://thedailywtf.com/Articles/Stupid-Coding-Tricks-The-TSQL-Madlebrot.aspx
@selenamarie Ah! That's more like it. Also, with recursive hurts my brain.
